data.title: Legacies of British Slavery
data.text:
1799

[Name] Potosi

[Crop] Sugar

Plotted in Trelawny as a sugar estate with a watermill in James Robertson's 1804 map of Jamaica.

To the King's most excellent Majesty, this map of the island of Jamaica, constructed from actual surveys. . . (London, J. Robertson, 1804), based on Robertson's survey of the county of Cornwall which he compeleted in 1799.

1805

[Name] Potosi Estate

The inventory of John Tharp (1805) gives his personal property of Potosi estate as having a value of Â£34,710 15s 0d.

Email from Anthony Gambrill sourced to John Tharp Details of Inventory Volume 104 Folio33 April24 1805.

1807

[Name] Potose

[Crop] sugar, rum and cattle

Account filed by Alexander McBean as overseer. Filed for 31st Oct 1806-30th Sept 1807.

Accounts Produce, Jamaica Archives 1B/11/4/37 20

1815

[Number of enslaved people] 309(Tot)

[Name] Potosi

[Stock] 174

Registered to heirs of John Tharp.

Jamaica Almanac (1816) transcribed at http://www.jamaicanfamilysearch.com/Members/AL15trel.htm. The almanac was based on the givings-in of the previous March Quarter, hence the earlier evolution date.

[Name] Portusi Estate

In the possession of William Fairclough and William Shand as the resident attornies & agents to the surviving trustees of the will of John Tharp Esquire deceased as owner.

T71/225 865-878
